In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  This technical assistance (TA) will help the Kyrgyz Republic, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan 
solve their water problems through the development of a water resources sector strategy in 
each  country  to  make  water  use  more  efficient  and  productive,  and  improve  agricultural 
productivity. These three countries were selected for this assistance because they (i) face water 
stress,1 (ii) have prioritized the water sector in their national development strategies, (iii) present 
potential windows for highlighting the water sector in their next Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
country partnership strategies, and (iv) are likely candidates for water-related project financing 
from ADB once strategies have been developed and potential projects identified.2 The TA is 
consistent with the ADB’s water operational plan for 2011-2020, which includes preparations of 
water  resources  sector  assessments  and  water  operational  plans  in  developing  member 
countries (DMCs) during 2011–2013, and will contribute to the plan’s output targets which 
include (i) sustainable ADB water lending of $2.0 billion–$2.5 billion annually or a total of $20 
billion–$25 billion by 2020, and (ii) the inclusion of increased water-use efficiency and/or water 
productivity  as  an  output  in  all  ADB’s  irrigation  projects  for  2012–2020. 3 The  TA  is  also 
consistent  with  ADB’s  Strategy  2020,  which  promotes  inclusive  economic  growth  and 
environmentally sustainable growth and supports investments in rural infrastructure, including 
irrigation and water management.4 The water resources sector is one of four sectors in which 
ADB’s Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) is committed to developing infrastructure. 5 
The governments of these three Central and West Asia DMCs have supported the concept of 
the proposed policy and advisory TA. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.6  
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Five of the ten DMCs in Central and West Asia suffer from water stress.7 Stress is 
highest in Uzbekistan, where it has reached 118%. It is followed, in order of severity, by 
Turkmenistan (101%), Pakistan (80%), Tajikistan (75%), and the Kyrgyz Republic (44%).8 This 
water  crisis  is  exemplified  by  the  continued  shrinking  of  the  Aral  Sea  in  Uzbekistan  and 
Kazakhstan,  which  depends  on  water  the  flow  from  the  Amu  Darya  and  the  Syr  Darya. 
Unsustainable withdrawals of water have reduced flow in the Amu Darya and resulted in the 
near-disappearance of a portion of the southern part of sea. This has led to deterioration of the 
ecosystem  and  in  the  economies  and  societies  that  depend  on  the  sea  and  downstream 
                                                
1 The TA uses one of two definitions of water stress, which is the ratio of withdrawals to available resources. The 
2006 United Nations World Water Development Report (UNDP, 2006; World Bank and IMF, 2008) presents the 
Relative Water Stress Index, defined as the ―ratio of total water use to renewable water supply‖ (UNESCO, 2006). 
Water stress exists for ratios above 40%, while physical scarcity is reached for ratios above 75% (UNESCO, 2006).  
2 ADB’s  partnership  strategy  for  Pakistan,  which  is  facing  serious  water  stress,  includes  the  water  sector. 
Turkmenistan, another water-stressed country, has no current national development strategy.  
3  ADB. 2011. Water Operational Plan, 2011–2020. Manila (approved on 13 October). 
4 ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila. 
5 The  water  resources  sector  includes  (i)  integrated  water  resources  management,  including  climate  change 
adaptation  and  mitigation;  (ii)  irrigation,  drainage,  and  flood  protection;  (iii)  water-based  natural  resources 
management; and (iv) irrigated land-based natural resources management (sustainable land management and 
conservation agriculture activity). Urban water and sanitation and rural drinking water supply are not covered by 
this TA. Urban water and sanitation are expected to be covered under an ongoing regional TA: ADB. 2011. 
Technical Assistance for the Preparation of Sector Road Maps for Central and West Asia. Manila. 
6  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 6 December 2011. 
7  Central Asia comprises Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and 
Uzbekistan. West Asia comprises Afghanistan and Pakistan.  
8  Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. Aquastat Country Fact Sheets. http://www.fao.org/nr/ 
water/aquastat/main/index.stm (accessed 13 September 2011). A withdrawal-to-water-supply rate of over 100% is 
possible because drainage return flows are reused.

2   
stretches  of  the  two  rivers.  In  addition,  frequent  water-related  disasters,  including  floods, 
mudflows, and droughts have impacted people and the economies in mountainous areas of the 
Kyrgyz Republic and Tajikistan.  
3.  Economic expansion, population growth, and unsustainable management of water use, 
especially for irrigation, have been adding to the already great pressure on the water resources 
and the environment in water-stressed countries. A shift of industry from agriculture to non-
agriculture sectors also demands better and more rational management of water resources.  
4.  Climate change is also affecting the balance in hydrological cycles and the availability of 
water resources. An example is the Pyanj River, which is a tributary of the Amu Darya, and has 
its river basin in Afghanistan and Tajikistan. The outputs of ADB’s previous TA for Tajikistan 
predicts in its river basin that (i) annual flow in some tributaries will increase until about 2080 
and then decrease as glaciers start disappearing; (ii) annual river flows will become more 
variable toward 2100 and high river flows will start earlier in some areas, as hydrological 
regimes are influenced more by rainfall-induced flows than by snow and ice melt; and (iii) 
annual evapotranspiration will increase in line with the predicted air temperature increase of 
about 3.5°C between 2010 and 2100.9 These climate change risks will be manifested as (i) 
increased demand for water, especially for irrigation, because of increasing temperatures and 
evapotranspiration,  potentially  leading  to  water  shortages,  and  (ii)  there  will  be  increasing 
socioeconomic damage due to higher annual melt water floods in the glacier-fed rivers. These 
potential climate change impacts, as well as the pressure to increase agriculture production to 
secure food supply, will make it more difficult to improve water management and may worsen 
water stress.  
5.  Several DMCs have neither strategies nor plans for prioritizing investments, and policy 
and institutional reforms in the water resources sector even though they are greatly needed to 
meet the challenges of water-use efficiency, water productivity, and agricultural productivity. 
This creates uncertainty about long-term government commitments to improvements in the 
water resources sector and makes it difficult for development partners to (i) reach agreements 
with  governments  on  strategic  directions,  (ii)  identify  these  governments’  most  important 
investment and reform needs, and (iii) finance investments in the sector. The government 
processes for identifying qualified water resources sector investments are also weak. 
6.  With a water stress level at 44% in the Kyrgyz Republic, the country’s medium-term 
development program for 2010–2014 makes irrigation one of eight priority sectors and requires 
an expenditure of $240 million to solve an irrigation water shortage in five southern districts. The 
program also requires (i) upgrading of the hydrometeorological data collection networks and (ii) 
rehabilitation of structures to protect populated areas and agricultural land from mudflows and 
floods.  
7.  The country development strategy for 2010–2014 in Tajikistan, which has a water stress 
level of 75%, calls for more efficient use of land and water, rebuilding and development of 
irrigation systems, and support for the formation of water users’ associations (WUAs). The 
strategy also emphasizes the need to reduce the land area affected by salinization and to 
ensure a reasonable supply of irrigation water to promote environmental sustainability.  
8.  The welfare implementation strategy for 2008–2010 in Uzbekistan, which suffers from 
the highest water stress in Central and West Asia (118%), calls for (i) substantially increasing 
                                                
9   ADB. 2010. Climate Resilience for Natural Resources Investments. Consultant’s report. Manila (TA 7599-TAJ).

3 
capital investment in irrigation and drainage, as well as modernizing pumping facilities and 
managing water resources more efficiently; (ii) gradually charging agricultural users’ for part of 
the cost of water they use to encourage efficiency; and (iii) improving the performance of WUAs, 
which  will  become  the  basic  grassroots  unit  in  efficient  water  resources  management. 
Investment projects will improve the efficient use of limited resources, including water.  
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome  
9.  The impact will be increased investments in sustainable and efficient management of 
water resources in the Kyrgyz Republic, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan.10 The TA outcome will be 
the use of 5- to 10-year water resources sector strategies starting 2013 by the governments of 
these  three countries for  water  resources management  planning to address  priority sector 
challenges.   
B.  Methodology and Key Activities  
10.  The TA output will be the development of a water resources sector strategy for each 
DMC. For each country, the output will include (i) a sector assessment; (ii) the sector strategy; 
(iii) a list of priority investment projects, including the investments and associated policy and 
institutional  reforms  and  capacity  development  to  meet  challenges  that  include  water-use 
efficiency, water productivity, and the agricultural productivity of water; (iv) concept papers for 
the priority investment projects selected from each country’s list; and (v) a knowledge product 
summarizing the process and outputs. The activities will be undertaken in two phases. 
11.  Phase  1  will  cover  (i) sector  assessments  to identify  and  prioritize  river  basin  and 
irrigation system challenges, (ii) development of sector strategies to propose solutions,  (iii) 
establishing criteria for selecting potential investment projects, and (iv) finalizing the scope and 
implementation arrangements of phase 2. Phase 1 will take 4 months, including 1 month in each 
country to assess the sector and develop a strategy. Phase 1 activities will be undertaken (i) 
first  in the  Kyrgyz  Republic;  (ii)  next  in  Uzbekistan;  and (iii)  last  in Tajikistan. The  sector 
strategies will not be comprehensive and will instead address the top three challenges in each 
country.  These  will  be  identified  through  consultations  with  ministries,  donors,  and 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs); reviews of documents and data; and simplified field 
surveys.11 Feedback from the government, donors, and NGOs will be discussed at a workshop 
when  finalizing  the  sector  assessment,  the  country  strategy,  and  the  criteria  for  selecting 
potential investment projects in each DMC.  
12.  Phase 2 will develop a list of priority investment projects, concept papers for the priority 
investment projects, and a knowledge product in each country.12 Phase 2 will take 8 months, 
including 1.5 months in each country to develop the lists, with the remaining time allotted to 
obtaining government endorsements and to produce the knowledge product. The list of priority

C.  Cost and Financing    
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.5 million, of which (i) $0.5 million will be financed on a 
grant basis by the Multi-Donor Trust Fund13 under the Water Financing Partnership Facility and 
administered by ADB, and (ii) $1.0 million will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  
 
14.  ADB  will  be  the  executing  agency  for  the  TA,  with  CWRD’s  Environment,  Natural 
Resources, and Agriculture Division as the focal point. ADB’s resident missions will support the 
TA  under  CWRD’s  joint  venture  approach.  The  Environment,  Natural  Resources,  and 
Agriculture Division will also be responsible for overall TA management and coordination. In 
each country, the ministry in charge of water resources management will be the implementing 
agency and the ministry or ministries in charge of national strategy planning and finance will 
provide  the  implementing  agency  with  strategic  guidance  and  support.  Each  participating 
government will appoint two main focal points in the implementing agency (one for decision 
making and another for administrative support) and one focal point each in the other ministry or 
ministries involved. The focal points are expected to review and endorse the key TA outputs.  
15.  The TA will require six international consultants (25 person-months) and nine national 
consultants (33 person-months). An international water management consultant will be team 
leader and the other international consultants will be responsible for (i) salinity management, (ii) 
irrigation management, (iii) agricultural development, (iv) image interpretation, and (v) economic 
evaluation. Phase 1 will require 10.5 person-months of international and 15.0 person-months of 
national consultancy, while phase 2 will need 14.5 person-months and 18.0 person-months of 
international and national consultant services, respectively. A consultant firm will be recruited for 
the two phases using a full technical proposal and weighted quality- and cost-based selection, 
which will apply a 90:10 ratio to reflect the additional challenges presented by differences and 
complexities of the water resources sectors in these three countries. ADB will also recruit one 
individual international consultant for 13 person-months to liaise with the consultant firm and the 
implementing agencies and to manage the delivery schedule and output quality. The consultant 
firm and the individual consultant will be selected in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA fund will be disbursed in 
accordance with the ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended 
from time to time).  
16.  The TA will be implemented from December 2011 to March 2013. The TA team will 
oversee the outputs of the TA activities, including comments on draft papers and coordination of 
missions to meet governments. The no-objection of each participating CWRD country will be 
confirmed before TA activities are financed and begin in that DMC.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Multi-Donor Trust Fund under the Water Financing Partnership 
Facility; and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a 
grant basis, for Developing Water Resources Sector Strategies in Central and West Asia, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Approach and Methodology 
 
1.  The TA will be implemented during December 2011–March 2013. The consultant team 
will conduct the TA in two phases over 12 months from April 2012 to March 2013. Phase 1 will 
require 10.5 person-months of international  and 15 person-months of national consultants. 
Depending on its scope, which is to be determined during phase 1, phase 2 is expected to 
require  another  14.5  person-months  of  international  consultants  and  18  person-months  of 
national consultancy. In addition, ADB will recruit one individual international consultant for 13 
person-months of input to liaise with the consultant team and the implementing agencies and to 
manage the delivery schedule and the quality of outputs. 
 
B.   Phase 1  
 
2.  Team leader and water management specialist (international, 3.5 person-months, 
intermittent). The specialist will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  He or she will liaise with ADB and the implementing agencies, lead the TA team, 
orient the other consultants, and integrate their outputs and ADB’s crosscutting 
themes;1 
(ii)  He or she will lead the country water resource assessments to identify and 
prioritize  the  main  water  sector  challenges  based  on  national  and/or  sector 
development strategies and investment plans and reports and discussions with 
relevant agencies, donors, and NGOs;  
(iii)  The specialist will estimate water supplies, demands, and balances for all users 
as well as expected climate change impacts at national and river basin levels. He 
or  she  will  distinguish  between  withdrawal,  reuse  of  drainage  flows,  and  all 
productive and non-productive consumptive uses; 
(iv)  This  specialist  will  assess  flood  protection  systems  and  management 
organizations and the importance of flood management relative to other priority 
national water sector challenges;  
(v)  He or she will also assess government policy and  institutional and staff capacity 
for integrated river basin management, infrastructure improvement, and main 
system management;  
(vi)  The  specialist  will  assess  irrigation  systems  and  their  present  and  potential 
performance  to  identify  causes,  not  symptoms,  of  poor  performance  and 
deteriorated infrastructure. He or she will establish the requirements for holistic 
system improvement rather than mere infrastructure rehabilitation;  
(vii)  He or she will also assess system operation and maintenance requirements and 
realistic costs;  
(viii)  The team leader will formulate integrated policy, infrastructure, and institutional 
solutions  and  strategies2 to  address  priority  sector  challenges.  Among  other 
things, and as required, these solutions may include (a) managing irrigated land,

3.  Salt  management  specialist  (international,  2  person-months  intermittent).  The 
specialist is directly responsible for basin-level salt management and/or irrigation system-level 
waterlogging,  salinity,  and  sub-surface  drainage  aspects  of  the  phase  1  outputs.  This  will 
include but not be restricted to the following: 
 
(i)  At the river basin-level, this specialist will (a) identify and assess irrigated, rain-
fed, and other primary salt sources; (b) account for water and salt and ensure 
inputs and outputs balance; (c) assess soil and water salinity; and (d) formulate 
salt management strategies; 
(ii)  At basin-level and/or irrigation system level, the specialist will assess (a) natural 
drainage,  (b)  water  salinity,  (c)  cost-effectiveness  of  providing  artificial 
subsurface drainage, and (e) suitability of existing irrigated land; and  
(iii)  The salt management specialist will help formulate solutions to priority problems 
and develop strategies and ranking criteria for (a) the integrated management of 
irrigated land, water, and salt at the river basin-level; and (b) improved salinity 
management at the system and field levels. 
 
4.  Irrigation management specialist (international, 2 person-months intermittent). The 
specialist  will  have  direct  responsibility  for  participatory  irrigation  management,  irrigation 
management transfer, water users’ associations (WUAs), and lower-level system and/or on-
farm water management (OFWM) outputs. These responsibilities will include but not be limited 
to:   
 
(i)  assessing strengths, weaknesses, opportunities in and threats to existing WUAs 
and their willingness to pay for specific main system management improvements;  
(ii)  assessing  government institutions, NGOs, other WUA support service providers, 
and their organizational capacities for community mobilization, WUA formation 
and  capacity  development  for  participatory  irrigation  management,  irrigation 
management transfer, and OFWM; and  
(iii)  contributing to (a) country water assessments to identify priority challenges at 
both river basin and system levels, (b) water sector strategies, and (c) criteria to 
select qualified potential investment projects.

5.  Agricultural development specialist (international, 2 person-months intermittent). The 
specialist will have direct responsibility for agricultural development, including aspects related to 
crop  diversification  and  production,  agronomy,  extension,  and  marketing.  The  specialist’s 
responsibilities will include but not be limited to the following:  
 
(i)  This specialist will compile, analyze, and interpret production statistics at lower 
administrative levels, assess crop yield gaps (potential minus present yields), 
identify constraints (including waterlogging, salinity, and water delivery inequities), 
and estimate their impacts. He or she will review, synthesize, update, and adapt 
the results and/or outputs of past ADB technical assistance; 6    
(ii)  The  specialist  will  assess  government  institutions,  NGOs,  WUAs,  and  other 
agricultural support services, as well as their organizational capacities; 
(iii)  With the irrigation management specialist, she or he will assess the WUAs’ 
potential role as agricultural extension intermediaries and propose partnerships 
between ADB and service providers; and  
(iv)  This  specialist  will  help  (a)  formulate  country  water  assessments  to  identify 
priority  challenges  at  both  national  and  river  basin  levels  and  water  sector 
strategies, and (b) develop project screening, ranking and selection criteria. 
 
6.  Economic  evaluation  specialist  (international,  1  person-month  intermittent).  The 
specialist will have direct responsibility for the economic evaluation aspects of phase 1 outputs. 
This will include but not be restricted to: 
 
(i)  assisting  the  irrigation  management  specialist  in  assessing  the  WUAs’ 
willingness to pay for main system improvements; 
(ii)  assessing the financing gap between the present levels and those required to 
address main water sector challenges in governments, beneficiaries, and donors; 
(iii)  assessing (a) government policies in terms of financing sharing structure, and (b) 
potential economic benefits and losses with and without addressing main water 
sector challenges; and 
(iv)  developing  and  applying  economic  efficiency  and  social  equity  criteria  and 
helping formulate (a) country water assessments to identify priority challenges at 
the national and river basin levels, (b) water sector strategies, and (c) criteria to 
screen and rank potential investment projects. 
 
7.  Country sector specialists (three per country, 15 person-months intermittent). In each 
country, one specialist will be responsible for each of these areas: (i) water management (i) 
irrigation and salt management, and (iii) agriculture. This will include economic and financial 
data collection, and remote sensing image interpretation (RSII)  for each area. Each water 
management specialist will be required for 2 person-months intermittently and each of the other 
specialists for 1.5 person-months intermittently. These specialists will: 
  
(i)  report  to  the  team  leader,  facilitate  liaison  and/or  agreements  with  the 
implementing agencies, and contribute to all aspects of the TA as required by the 
team leader;

(ii)  collect relevant required information from government agencies, donors, NGOs, 
and academia, and analyze them as requested by the team leader;  
(iii)  support  the  country  water  assessment  to  identify,  analyze,  and  prioritize 
challenges; and 
(iv)  support the water sector strategy with solutions to address the challenges. 
 
C.   Phase 2  
 
8.  Subject to the approval of the phase 2 scope and arrangements to be prepared under 
phase 1, each consultant is expected to report to the team leader; help refine the project 
screening, ranking and selection criteria; help apply them to investment plans; help prioritize the 
most  promising  investment  projects to  implement  the  strategy;  and  help  prepare the  draft 
concept papers.  
 
9.  Team  leader  (international,  4.5  person-months  intermittent).  During  phase  2,  the 
responsibilities of the team leader and water management specialist will  likely include the 
following: 
 
(i)  He or she will apply screening, ranking, and selection criteria to investment plans 
and identify and prioritize investment projects to implement the strategy;  
(ii)  The team leader will prepare (a) practical main irrigation system infrastructure 
and  management  outputs,  (b)  arrangements  for  implementation  and 
organizational and human resources capacity development, and (c) associated 
policy and institutional reforms, if required, for inclusion in the draft concept 
papers (DCP) for the priority investment projects in each country;  
(iii)  The team leader will coordinate inputs and prepare the overall DCPs7 for the 
priority projects in each country, using the ADB template. The DCPs will include 
(a) the modalities (project preparatory technical assistance and/or project design 
facility),8  (b) problem tree analysis and design and monitoring frameworks,9  (c) 
implementation arrangements, (d) approaches and methodologies,  
(e) estimated costs, (f) initial poverty and social analyses, and (g) consultant 
terms of reference for the selected modality. The approaches and methodologies 
will include participatory POW performance assessments and diagnoses to (a) 
assess system performance, (b) diagnose constraints, and (c) formulate practical 
improvements to alleviate them and optimize system performance; and        
(iv)  The team leader will prepare and disseminate three draft final country reports in 
English  and  Russian,  facilitate  stakeholder  workshops  to  review  them, 
incorporate  comments,  complete  the  three  final  reports,  facilitate  formal 
government  endorsement  of  the  outputs,  and  develop  and  disseminate 
knowledge products summarizing the process and outputs.    
 
10.  Salt  management  specialist  (international,  2  person-months,  intermittent).  The 
specialist will (i) take responsibility at the system level for (a) quantifying the extent and severity 
of soil salinity, (b) assessing soil salinity impacts on the agricultural productivity of water, (c) 
assessing the effectiveness of sub-surface drainage systems and infrastructure, (d) identifying

not the symptoms but the causes of poor performance, and (e) establishing the requirements for 
holistic system improvement; and (ii) prepare practical subsurface drainage infrastructure and 
salinity  management  outputs  and  implementation  and  organizational  capacity  development 
arrangements. 
 
11.  Irrigation management specialist (international, 2 person-months, intermittent). The 
specialist will prepare practical lower-level irrigation system infrastructure, management, and 
OFWM outputs as well as implementation and organizational (government irrigation agency and 
WUA) capacity development arrangements. 
 
12.  Agricultural development specialist (international, 2 person-months, intermittent). The 
specialist will (i) help refine and apply screening and ranking criteria, apply them to investment 
plans, and prioritize investment projects to implement the agreed strategy; and (ii) prepare 
practical agricultural development and OFWM outputs for selected projects, and implementation 
and organizational capacity development arrangements.  
 
13.  Image  interpretation  specialist  (international,  2  person-months  intermittent).  The 
specialist will: 
  
(i)  work with the irrigation and salt management specialists to assess the potential 
to  use  RSII  to  estimate  (a)  the  extent  and  severity  of  soil  salinity;  and  (b) 
irrigation efficiency, crop water consumption, the POW, and other parameters as 
technical inputs to participatory performance assessments and diagnoses and 
project formulation; and 
(ii)  prepare  detailed  RSII  proposals  for  incorporation  into  DCPs,  with  (a) 
implementation  arrangements,  (b)  approaches  and  methodologies,  and  (c) 
estimated costs.  
 
14.   Economic  evaluation  specialist  (international,  2  person-months  intermittent).  The 
economic evaluation specialist will (i) refine and apply economic efficiency and social equity 
criteria to identify projects, and (ii) undertake initial economic evaluation of the top project in 
each country following ADB’s guidelines on the economic analysis of projects.10 
 
15.  Country sector specialists (three per country, each 2 person-months intermittent). In 
each country, one country sector specialist will be responsible for each of these areas: (i) water 
management, (ii) irrigation and salt management, and (iii) agriculture. They will (i) support 
development  of  investment  priorities  to  implement  the  agreed  strategy,  and  (ii)  support 
preparation of DCPs for the top project in their country. 
 
D.  Senior  water  resources  management  specialist  (international,  13  person-months 
intermittent).  
 
16.  During TA’s implementation period from December 2011 to March 2013, the senior 
water resources management specialist will: (i) liaise with the consultants and the implementing 
agencies to facilitate working arrangements; (ii) participate in review missions and oversee TA 
progress, constraints, and required remedial actions to facilitate efficient delivery of effective TA 
outputs; and (iii) conduct other duties agreed between the ADB project officer and the specialist. 
The specialist will produce quarterly progress reports and submit the reports to the ADB project 
officer.
